description.narrative: # of women led CSOs with increased L&A capacities.

comment.narrative: Compared to neighbouring Kenya and Uganda, key population community mobilisation in Burundi is limited. Programming for sex workers is the most developed out of all the key populations, though only one sex worker-led organisation is currently functioning, with their development supported by the African Sex Worker Alliance. The community of people who use drugs (PWUD) is primarily organised through the Burundi Association of People who Use Drugs (BAPUD), which has worked to establish effective cooperation with the Burundian police and has ensured that funding for two methadone clinics is included within the Global Fund 2021-2023 country grant. LGBTIQ+ organising is challenged particularly by being French speaking in a region who are English speakers; nevertheless, organizing in this community has growing momentum and has developed and implemented cross-country and regional programs with colleagues in the DRC especially around safety and security and in the movement strengthening pieces of work (Context Analysis, 2020).

At least 6 organisations led by Women groups from communities of Sexual and Gender Minorities, Sex Workers or Persons Who Use Drugs, have increased capacity to advocate for KP rights.This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

Support to strengthen capacities of sex workers organising
Grantee partner which is a female sex worker led organisation, fights against all forms of sex trafficking and seeks to improve sex workers’ living conditions, their mental and physical health.
Since the Pandemic began, there has been significant loss of income. The closure of places of work, lockdowns, self-isolation, travel restrictions, curfews resulted into significant if not total loss of revenue streams for sex workers. Many sex workers couldn’t access basic necessities, such as food, shelter and water. Majority have grown-ups and children who depend on them, this situation exacerbated the financial instability and exerted economic pressure on sex workers which forced some of them to ignore the risk of contracting COVID-19 in order to earn a living.
Through UHAI support the grantee partner led capacity building initiatives for her members. They were able to observe COVID-19 prevention measures (Hand washing, wearing masks and social distancing) They were trained on COVID-19 symptoms and equipped with information on testing centre,contributing to reducing COVID-19 virus transmission.
Grantee partner was able to work in close collaboration with LGBTI organisations working in Burundi in some of the HIV/AIDS control programmes, more specifically those run by L’ANSS (the Burundi National Association for support to people living with HIV and AIDS). Grantee partner collaborated with other CSOs (in the drug users project). Together, they have created UBUNTU which is a platform through which they can find solutions to their common challenges.
Through strategic partnership with a KP-led organisation in Burundi, grantee partner was mentored on project management and related technical skills. This female sex worker--led organisation is already leading peer capacity building from UHAI’s existing grantees. As the organisation seeks to advance its national work that influences issues affecting sex workers, they benefited more in gaining such technical expertise through experiential learning. This is beyond the traditional technical skills and acquisition of knowledge through training.

comment.narrative: Compared to neighbouring Kenya and Uganda, key population community mobilisation in Burundi is limited. Programming for sex workers is the most developed out of all the key populations, though only one sex worker-led organisation is currently functioning, with their development supported by the African Sex Worker Alliance. The community of people who use drugs (PWUD) is primarily organised through the Burundi Association of People who Use Drugs (BAPUD), which has worked to establish effective cooperation with the Burundian police and has ensured that funding for two methadone clinics is included within the Global Fund 2021-2023 country grant. 6 Organisations in Burundi led by groups of Sexual and Gender Minorities have increased capacities to advocate for rights of KP communities. This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

2 KP-led organisations in Burundi were supported to build their capacity.
1. By supporting this grantee partner to engage in a peer learning and exchange process exchange with an established Trans-led organisation that has builtits expertise in working on transgender issues, which would allow them to acquire knowledge on how to design programs that speaks to the needs of their constituents in Burundi.
Following their participation in their peer learning and exchange that was cognisant of the COVID 19 protocols around travel, grantee partner has been able to develop organisational governance and administrative and leadership skills, as well as advocacy and communication skills. This has ensured that they are able to design programs that speak to the needs that speak to the needs of the Trans community in Burundi. It is expected that in the long term TIA will be able to advance their advocacy work that is able to target various decision makers through strategic communications skills acquired through the peer to peer learning and support.
There were 2 participants from the grantee partner organisation and 4 from another UHAI grantee partner. The grantee partner in Burundi gained knowledge of strategic organizational leadership techniques such as decision making and plan implementation Knowledge of leadership processes such as strategic planning, conflict management and staff development. They now have knowledge of organizational leadership techniques, strategies such as decision making and implementing plans, as well as leadership processes such as strategic planning, communication, conflict management and staff development.The grantee partner has been able to put in place the documents that will be shared with partners and donors, which speaks clearly and precisely about the history and life of the organisation, which is shared with all staff members and stored in their organisational records
2. Our support to this grantee partner has strengthened their capacity to advance peer led capacity support which has led to the development of indigenous SOGIE knowledge tailored to local contexts. This has fostered the emergence of LGBTIQ leaders at the national and sub-regional levels.
This support further led to the co-designing of learning modules on areas of interest mainly: gender and sexuality, human rights, leadership, and security programming with the communities they work with following an open call by those interested. enhancing the operational capabilities of emerging and embryonic community-based organisations, by ensuring they are responsive to their constituents hence strengthening their legitimacy. Grantee partner has been able to provide strategic thinking assistance to new and emerging organisations who fall within their capacity development processes.
Collective learning and knowledge transfer which was a focus of this intervention has further strengthened previous work of building the foundations of knowledge management at a regional level between Burundi, Rwanda and DRC which will further build solidaries across the geographies.
This intervention has so far contributed to making capacity strengthening work involving skills building of individuals and organisations in Burundi in ways that are impactful as in indigenously developed. This continued to strengthen our partners in fostering peer-led participatory processes.
In the long term, it is expected that this work will contribute to providing organisations with a culture of collective problem-solving, quick solutions and development of knowledge and new skills while decreasing the competitive spirit among partners.
This will further contribute to the emergence of new practices that grantee partner constituents will experiment and adopt.
This intervention has further expanded collective learning, knowledge transfer, and knowledge management at a regional level.
A community webinar with activists from the region was held that brought together activists and donors from Burundi, Rwanda, DRC, and Congo. The space served as a community framework for exchange on the evolving context with various groups established in the region.
A community of practice (CoP) by organising a group learning workshop for LGBTIQ organisations to share and transfer knowledge, every three months was created.
The COP provided organisations with a culture of collective problem-solving, providing quick solutions and developing knowledge and new skills while decreasing the competitive spirit. It has contributed to the emergence of new practices that their members can test and which will be given back to the collective.

description.narrative: # of by-laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: Government attention to key populations has grown due to influence by the international and local advocates, and there is enough material and information relayed via both soft and physical training enhancing the awareness levels of key populations needs in Burundi (Context Analysis, 2020). HIV CSO’s have also trained an array of stakeholders from different sectors on key populations, thus creating an informed and skilled workforce. LGBTIQ+ CSO’s have also engaged in SRHR conversations and with these efforts, information is available online and via other mediums (Context Analysis, 2020).
4 by -laws for sustainable and inclusive development that are better implemented as a result of CSO engagement. This is a target for all the 5 years i.e. 2021 - 2025

UHAI supported 2 grantee organisations in Burundi to attend ICASA in Durban, South Africa. This created a learning space for partners to evaluate funding for Key Populations and also create space for building their capacities on how to engage with funders. Partners were able to derive specific action named Durban Declaration to use in influencing the country funding both at the national and at the bilateral level. Partners also increased learning and skills on PEPFAR funding in the run-up to the COP 21 and advocacy for more targeted funding for communities.
This meeting was very strategic as immediately after a member of UHAI’s grantee partner organisation was nominated to be a representative of KPS on PEPFAR. UHAI linked them with Health Gap as support to the KP representative on capacity building on how to engage with PEPFAR in Burundi.
